description: From Middle English chavel, from Old English ċeafl (“a bill, beak, snout, jaw, jaw-bone, cheek, cheek-bone”), from Proto-West Germanic *kafl, from Proto-Germanic *kaflaz (“jaw”). Doublet of jowl; see there for more.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The jaw, especially of an animal.

verbs.description: chavel (third-person singular simple present chavels, present participle chavelling, simple past and past participle chavelled)

examples: The bracken lay sere under the trees, broken and chavelled by the restless wild winds of the long winter.
